description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention

This project was established to provide the support to overcome the barriers that currently prevent widespread and sustainable utilization of Renewable Energy Technologies for the provision of energy services in rural areas of Thailand.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
Energy - power generation
1) Increase of power generation capacity and usage from RE systems in MHS both on-grid and off-grid; 2) Models for RE generation & application which can be replicated in other areas demonstrated

comment.narrative: 1) RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29,220 MW on grid and 255 kW off-grid (June 2014); 2) No new models for RE generation & application.

By the end of the project: 1) RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29,720 MW on grid and more than 315 kW off- grid by the project's additional RE power generation capacity of 500 kW (solar farm) and 60 kW off grid hydro) and several solar applications realized. 2) At least 3 new models for RE generation & application developed and operational. Models ready to be replicated in other areas (hydro, solar and biodigesters).
1) Project’s additional RE power generation capacity to MHS: 2.5 kW (on-grid) and 12.71 kW (off-grid); 2) 4 new RE models developed & tried out, replicable.

By the end of the project: 1) RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29,720 MW on grid and more than 315 kW off- grid by the project's additional RE power generation capacity of 500 kW (solar farm) and 60 kW off grid hydro) and several solar applications realized. 2) At least 3 new models for RE generation & application developed and operational. Models ready to be replicated in other areas (hydro, solar and biodigesters).

1) Project’s additional RE power generation capacity to MHS: 18.28 kW (on-grid) and 13.26 kW (off-grid); or cumulative result of additional RE power generation capacity to MHS by the project = 93.85 kW (69.40 kW on grid and 34.75 kW off-grid); 2) More 3 new RE models developed & tried out, replicable; or cumulative result = 7 RE models developed/ replicable.

description.narrative: Project Objective To overcome barriers to the provision of Renewable Energy RE services in integrated provincial renewable energy programmes in Thailand

By the end of the project RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 2706 MW on grid and more than 24 MW offgrid This is equivalent to an increase of at least 55000 MWhyear
RE power generation capacity in MHS amounts to 29220 MW on grid and 255 kW offgrid June 2015

description.narrative: Models for RE generation application which can be replicated in other areas demonstrated

At least 3 new models for RE generation application developed and operational Models ready to be replicated in other areas hydro solar and biodigesters

Several models related to RE generation application service delivery fund management and sustainable utilization of RE were sketched out but not finalized For instance policy support for RE applications energy access in forest reserved area facilitation to local government in RE technologies operation maintenance OM community management for productive uses of RE technologies women empowerment in ICS realization and promotion RE revolving fund Clean Energy Fund for income generation and livelihoods improvement for the marginalized groups

title.narrative: Mangroves for the Future (MFF)/ Small Grants Facility

description.narrative: Mangroves for the Future (MFF)/ Small Grants Facility (SGF)
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Total number of additional people benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste

The Mangrove For the Future is a regional initiative involving six Indian Ocean countries that were affected by the Tsunami on December 2004. It was established to emphasis on improving live conditions of its coastal habitants.
first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
- Replication of good practices - Improved fertility of coastal resources shown by catching statistics - Co-management system set up

comment.narrative: - Individual practices; by 1.5 years, good practices of community-based resources management have been part of local school curriculum - Depletion of marine and coastal resources; by 1.5 years, 30% increase of CBOs working on sustainable resources management - No coordination with local government; by 1.5 years, CBOs at the target areas have formed its network in natural resources management
5-6 project grantees formed under MFF framework

1) 9 small projects implemented by community conservation groups, organizations and foundations under MFF framework; 2) The project networks in the target communities are strong and there is collaboration with relevant agencies within and outside the locality, in accordance with the project plans; 3) The community members have heightened concern about preservation and rehabilitation of the ecosystem, especially regarding the potential benefits to their households; 4) The target communities have the capacity to develop a database and conduct knowledge management to create useful learning packages; 5) The community was able to apply knowledge and skills in managing their projects and developing alternative occupations to generate supplemental income.
No Operation

title.narrative: Strengthening Thailand Capacity to Link Climate Policy

description.narrative: Strengthening Thailand Capacity to Link Climate Policy and Public Finance

title.narrative: Project Document- Strengthening Thailand's Capacity to Link Climate Policy and Public Finance
RFP for the provision of Budget/Fiscal Analysis of Climate Change of the project on ?Strengthening Thailand?s Capacity to link climate Policy and Public Finance?.
RFP for the provision of the provision of Economic Analysis of Climate Change of the project on ?Strengthening Thailand?s Capacity to link climate Policy and Public Finance?

description.narrative: This three-year project (2013-2015) aims to strengthen Thailand's capacity to link climate policy and public finance/ and develop an efficient and effective monitoring and evaluation framework.
capital of a political entity

(1) Availability of technical tools developed to mainstream Climate Change into sectoral development planning and budgeting (2) Number of budget requests from sectoral agencies incorporating climate change analysis formulated and submitted to the Bureau of Budget (3) Availability of the common framework for Climate Change analysis at the project and programme level to be integrated as criteria for the Bureau of Budget’s consideration for budget appropriation (4) Availability of options for inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangements for climate finance

comment.narrative: (1) 0 (2) 0 (3) Climate Public Expenditures and Institutional Review (CPEIR) completed in 2012 but recommendations not yet developed into a common framework for budget requests and appropriation (4) No inter-agency coordination and institutional arrangement mechanism for climate finance

(1) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis as a tool for climate change planning and budgeting widely communicated to related government agencies for policy advocacy (2) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis submitted to the National Climate Change Committee for views and comments (3) Training Module based on the Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis developed (4) Communication materials related to climate change benefit analysis works undertaken during 2013-15 developed and shared with general public

(1) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis widely communicated to related government agencies through workshops, high level policy forum, social media, and website (2) Guidelines for Climate Change Benefit Analysis submitted to the National Climate Change Committee in July and further actions on modification and revision were recommended (3) Training Module to be finalized in January 2017 (4) Communication materials i.e. policy briefs, info-graphic, animation etc. developed and shared with general public

(1) Training on Climate Change Benefit Analysis conducted based on the module developed (2) Partnership with a potential training Institute to run a regular (yearly/bi-annually) CCBA training for government officials established (3) project document for second phase of climate finance project prepared and drafted

(1) Training on Climate Change Benefit Analysis conducted in February-March 2017 with approximately 40 government officials atteding (2) Partnership with Thailand's Greenhouse Gas Management Organization established to use the training module for future training on CCBA (3) Drafting of the 2nd phase of climate fiannce project (funded by SIDA) undertaken and the final project document will be completed in Q1 2018

description.narrative: (1) Thailand's national GHG inventory system is updated and and improved (2) V&A assessment approaches and management is improved to deal with risks of climate change, climate variability and extreme weather events (3) Analysis and national capacity on mitigation options is improved (4) Information on national circumstances, constraints, needs and other relevant information is updated including public awareness on the relevance of BUR and TNC (5) The first BUR of Thailand and capacity building on NAMA, MRV, and national registry system are developed (6) BUR and TNC reports are prepared, translated, and published in Thai and English language.

comment.narrative: Second national communication (SNC) report Technology Needs Assessemnt (TNA) report in inventory, mitigation, V&A, research, and systematic observation Technical Review

(1) Conducted preliminary assessment of Thailand's national GHG inventory system to update for TNC and BUR and improvement consideration (2) Initiated V&A assessment approaches and management is improved to deal with risks of climate change, climate variability and extreme weather events (3) Initiated analysis and national capacity on mitigation options is improved (4) Initiated information on national circumstances, constraints, needs and other relevant information is updated including public awareness on the relevance of BUR and TNC (5) Initiated first BUR of Thailand and capacity building on NAMA, MRV, and national registry system are developed (6) N/A

1) 0 2) 0 3) 0 4) 0 Key progress towards outcome were as follows: - The feasibility study on alternative livelihoods for communities in the buffer zone of HKK started - Additional equipment e.g. GPS, camera traps, vehicles, were provided to strengthen the patrolling system as well as tiger research coverage.

1) 0 2) 0 3) 0 4) 0 Key progress towards outcomes were as follows: Government adoption of the SMART Training and daily ration for the rangers influence capacity strengthening and moral support of park rangers to achieve the target of World Heritage protection. Innovative Wildlife-based Ecotuourism has been conceptually adopted by the Provincial administrative office and proceed towards the development plan. Pilot communities are seeking possibility in transforming the monocropping into integrated farming and/ or wildlife-friendly initiatives. Pioneers of innovative technology for the SMART protection and wildlife habitat management are contracted. This includes the youth leaders platform and networking to enhance governance and participatory joint management of the World Heritage Site.

Other General Services - support to civil society

Recognising the importance of a sustained support to peace-building in the current project on Southern Thailand Empowerment and Participation (STEPII), the project now will focuses more on the importance of SDGs 16, namely strong institutions, especially at local level, and local actors including local government, youth and women, in order to provide opportunities for those communities to be more resilient, overcoming restrictions and bottlenecks for their economic inclusion.

description.narrative: PIMS4839 FS Conserving Habitats for Globally Important Flora and Fauna in Production Landscapes
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The project covers Buririam, Samut Sakorn and Ranong Province, Thailand

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: The project covers Buririam, Samut Sakorn and Ranong Province, Thailand

description.narrative: 1) Hectares of production landscapes legislated as ES critical habitats and protection enforced to assure the long-term survival of ES in Thailand; 2) Status of species on the National Red list..

comment.narrative: 1) There are currently no areas of production landscape that are formally protected due to their importance to an endangered species; 2) Thailand currently has 1,058 species identified as threatened within the country’s National Red list of which 6 are extinct.

1) At least 33,893 ha legislated as ES Critical Habitats and managed in a manner that assures the long-term survival of target ES– based on: 600 ha of salt pans in Khok Kham Sub-district; 4,800 ha – which includes 1 km buffer around the 3 non-hunting areas in Buriram Province; and 28,493 ha which is the entire Nakha Subdistrict; 2) No overall decline in species status of species currently listed on the National Red list for Thailand (i.e. movement from one category to another).

1) At least 33,893 ha legislated as ES Critical Habitats and managed in a manner that assures the long-term survival of target ES– based on: 600 ha of salt pans in Khok Kham Sub-district; 4,800 ha – which includes 1 km buffer around the 3 non-hunting areas in Buriram Province; and 28,493 ha which is the entire Nakha Subdistrict; 2) No overall decline in species status of species currently listed on the National Red list for Thailand (i.e. movement from one category to another).

1) 0 2) Not yet achieved
The key progress towards result were: - An organic rice manufacturer group was established with currently 29 pilot members, with guidelines and documentation for registration with Community Organizations Development Institute (Public Organization): CODI, under the Ministry of Social Development and Human Security; - The monitoring system to track the crane survival rate in the wild set-up.

Target 1 Establish the Project Board and TGO's working group Target 2 Establish Project Management Unit Target 3 Sign MOU between TGO and the participating cities Target 4 Implement the project inception phase: low carbon projects identification Target 5 Participate in atleast 2 national and international events

Result 1 Project Board and TGO's Working Group established Result2 All positions recruited, i.e. Project Manager, Finanical Officer, Admin Officer and Project Coordinating Associate Result 3 MOU between TGO and the 4 participating cities signed Result 4 The inception phase implemented. Low carbon projects in 4 participtaing cities identified through 2 processes: a) desktop and interview with cities and b) stakeholder consultation with the Mayors and the city team Result 5 Participated in 1 national, 1 regional and 1 intenational events

description.narrative: Advancing Anti-corruption Efforts in Thailand - A Multifaceted Approach (AAA) Project.

This project combines a number of initiatives, including mitigating corruption risks in public procurement; youth empowerment and integrity education; and social entrepreneurship and social innovations in the fight against corruption.
capital of a political entity
Anti corruption

Indicators for Output 1 1.1 Number of drafted legal framework 1.2 Number of strategy and roadmap for building an efficient institutional structure for the new Public Procurement Law developed and adopted 1.3 Number of national public procurement training and professionalisation strategy developed
